num_tested_probands: The patient was the only proband tested in this report.
The patient was the first and only child born to non-consanguineous parents, indicating that there is no family history of genetic disorders.
The patient is the only proband tested in this report.
num_positive_het_probands: No probands were reported to be heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
No proband was found to be heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
No heterozygous probands were reported to have pathogenic variants.
positive_phenotypes: The patient presented with infantile-onset, Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism, which is a clinical hallmark of Parkin's disease.
The patient exhibited infantile-onset Parkinsonism and leukoencephalopathy, which are characteristic features of the disorder.

The patient has infantile-onset Levodopa-responsive Parkinsonism and infantile-onset Parkinsonism. The first family carried one of the alleles found in our patient (p.Trp13Gly), along with a frameshift mutation predicted to result in loss of function; the latter may account for the more severe intellectual disability seen in the affected siblings.
No clinical phenotypes were reported for positive probands.
num_compound_or_double_hets: One compound/heterozygous mutation was reported in the WARS2 gene.
The patient was compound heterozygous for two variants in the WARS2 gene: c.37T>G (p.Trp13Gly) and c.683C>G (p.Ser228Trp).
The patient has compound heterozygous mutations in WARS2.
No compound or double heterozygotes were reported.

quote_snippets: The patient was first noted to have left leg tremor while learning to stand at the age of 1.
At 18 months, the left leg tremor spread to his right leg and he was noted to have expressive language delay despite good receptive language skills.
Symptoms were severe enough to warrant a trial of Levodopa. After a trial dose of Levodopa, lower extremities tremor and dystonia disappeared for an entire day.
While the clinical presentations vary substantially among the reported WARS2 cases and our own patient, there are some shared similarities.

The first family carried one of the alleles found in our patient (p.Trp13Gly), along with a frameshift mutation predicted to result in loss of function; the latter may account for the more severe intellectual disability seen in the affected siblings.
This difference likely reflects the unique impact that a specific variant in WARS2 can have on the resulting cellular and clinical phenotype, or different methodologies.
